lines.content: Implement a skeletal version of Duke that starts by greeting the user, simply echos commands entered by the user, and exits when the user types bye.
What can I do for you?
Bye. Hope to see you again soon!
The indentation and horizontal lines are optional.
You are strongly encouraged to customize the chatbot name, command/display formats,
and even the personality of the chatbot to make your chatbot unique.
a. Create a constant variable storing greet message
2. echo commands from user input - DONE
a. can use a switch case following user input
3. exit command upon user input: "bye" - DONE
a. upon "bye" command -> output a exit message (stored in a constant variable)
4. Create a user friendly interface - DONE
a. Can use '\t' and "====" to create simple line blocks
Add the ability to store whatever text entered by the user and display them back to the user when requested.
What can I do for you?
Bye. Hope to see you again soon!
There is no need to save the data to the hard disk.
Assume there will be no more than 100 tasks. If you wish, you may use a fixed size array (e.g., String[100]) to store the items.
1. Save text of user input - Done
- Use ArrayList to store texts of user input (String type)
- Iterate through String arraylist of stored text
Add the ability to mark tasks as done.
Here are the tasks in your list:
Nice! I've marked this task as done:
When implementing this feature, you are also recommended to implement the following extension:
↳ Use a class to represent tasks
While it is possible to represent a task list as a multi-dimensional array containing primitive values, the more natural approach is to use a Task class to represent tasks.
-to keep track of String task and a boolean isDone - DONE
- constructor to create task and set isDone false as default - DONE
- use toString() -> to display task -- format: [] (task name) - DONE
2. Ability to mark task by index in list
- Change ArrayList to store Task instead of String
- Change add command to store task in arraylist
- change behavior of list command for Task
Add support for tracking three types of tasks:
ToDos: tasks without any date/time attached to it e.g., visit new theme park
Deadlines: tasks that need to be done before a specific date/time e.g., submit report by 11/10/2019 5pm
Events: tasks that start at a specific time and ends at a specific time e.g., team project meeting on 2/10/2019 2-4pm
Got it. I've added this task:
Now you have 5 tasks in the list.
Here are the tasks in your list:
Got it. I've added this task:
Now you have 6 tasks in the list.
Got it. I've added this task:
Now you have 7 tasks in the list.
At this point, dates/times can be treated as strings; there is no need to convert them to actual dates/times.
Got it. I've added this task:
Now you have 6 tasks in the list.
↳ Use Inheritance to support multiple task types
As there are multiple types of tasks that have some similarity between them, you can implement classes T0do, Deadline and Event classes to inherit from a Task class.
Furthermore, use polymorphism to store all tasks in a data structure containing Task objects e.g., Task[100].
- need to be done before a specific date/time
* Gnosis class is the main programme to execute chatbot assistant.
* Commands Gnosis can provide a task tracker to user:
* "done (task number)" - marks specified task as done
* default - adds user input as task
private static final String GREET_MESSAGE = "Welcome, I am Gnosis.\n" +
"The spark to meet your needs.\nHow can I assist you ?";
private static final String BYE_MESSAGE = "Good bye.\nI hope your needs have been sparked.\n" +
// terminates user input only when "bye" is inputted by user
public static void executeCommand(String command, String input) {
// convert command to lower case to avoid case issues
// only if "done" command is call, we retrieve task index from user
System.out.println("Listing all tasks in your list:");
System.out.println("COMMAND NOT FOUND.\nPlease try another command.");
System.out.println("Total tasks in the list: " + tasks.size());
* The Task class encapsulates a task with a String and
* whether the task is done or not.
